meanings.def: to fasten one thing to another or make something tight with a screw or screws
examples: The bookcase is screwed to the wall.
You need to screw all the parts together.
She screwed the lock into the door.
The bed was screwed to the floor.

meanings.def: to turn something round and round in order to fasten it in place
examples: screw something + adv./prep. She screwed the cap back on the jar.
screw something + adj. Screw the bolt tight.
The bulb should just screw into the socket.

meanings.def: to use your hand to make something, especially a piece of paper, form a tight ball
examples: screw something up (into something) I screwed up the letter and threw it into the fire.
screw something (up) into something Screw the foil into a little ball.

meanings.def: to cheat somebody, especially by making them pay too much money for something
examples: screw somebody for something How much did they screw you for (= how much did you have to pay)?

meanings.def: to force somebody to give you something
examples: They screwed the money out of her by threats.

meanings.def: an offensive way of showing that you are annoyed or do not care about somebody/something
to force yourself to be brave enough to do something
examples: I finally screwed up my courage and went to the dentist.

idioms.idiom: have your head screwed on (the right way)

meanings.def: a thin pointed piece of metal like a nail with a raised spiral line (called a thread) along it and a line or cross cut into its head. Screws are turned and pressed into wood, metal, etc. with a screwdriver in order to fasten two things together.
examples: One of the screws is loose.

meanings.def: an act of turning a screw
a propeller on a ship, a boat or an aircraft
to be slightly strange in your behaviour
to force somebody to do something by frightening and threatening them
an extra amount of pressure, cruelty, etc. added to a situation that is already difficult to bear or understand
